hypothesis_content.title: ETH/BTC Ratio Reversion on Spot-CVD Divergence
hypothesis_content.statement: In a NEUTRAL regime, when the ETH/BTC ratio (4h) deviates more than 2.5% from its 10-day rolling mean, and a strong divergence forms between the ratio's price trend and the 4h Cumulative Volume Delta (CVD) for ETH spot markets, a mean-reverting trade in the ratio (long BTC/short ETH or vice versa) initiated at the divergence's confirmation candle close is profitable before the ratio returns to its 20-day Bollinger Band.
hypothesis_content.rationale: In neutral, range-bound markets, large deviations in the core ETH/BTC ratio are often driven by fleeting sentiment or leveraged flows. A divergence with the CVD—a proxy for net spot market order flow—suggests the move lacks sustainable buying/selling pressure. This creates a high-probability setup for the ratio to revert towards its mean as unsustainable momentum fades.
entry_conditions: Divergence: Ratio makes a higher high (lower low) over 5 periods, while 4h ETH Spot CVD makes a lower high (higher low)
Trigger: Close of the 4h candle confirming the divergence (e.g., ratio's new high close with CVD failing to confirm)
Position: Short ETH/BTC ratio if bearish divergence (ratio high, CVD low); Long ratio if bullish divergence.

exit_conditions.take_profit: ETH/BTC ratio crosses its 10-day simple moving average
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Ratio moves an additional 1.5% against the trade entry beyond the divergence extreme point

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: More than 60% of trades are stopped out before the ratio touches its 10-day SMA, indicating the divergence is not a reliable exhaustion signal in current market microstructure.
